title: Prohibits discrimination by insurers because of past travel history
summary: Prohibits discrimination by insurers solely because of an applicant's or insured's past lawful travel experiences or history; provides a person's past lawful travel experiences or history shall not be a permitted underwriting criterion.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2046

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the insurance law, in relation to prohibiting discrimination by
insurers because of past travel history

PURPOSE:
This bill prohibits discrimination by insurers because of
past travel history.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 adds a new section 2606-a to the
insurance law. It provides that no insurer shall discriminate solely
based upon past travel history. No insurer may refuse to issue or
renew, deny or cancel any insurance policy or contract. They may not
demand a higher premium from the insured nor fix any lower rates in
the fees collected (i.e. no lower rates for those not traveling
outside the country).

An insurer that complies with this provision in good faith shall not
be subjected to civil liability.

Section 2 enacts this bill on the ninetieth day after it shall become
law.

JUSTIFICATION:
Insurers should not arbitrarily subject their customers
to penalties based upon their travel experiences or future travel
plans. Risk should never be assigned to past events. Moreover, this
practice would unfairly discriminate against persons participating in
religious retreats, pilgrimages, and sojourns.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after
it shall have become a law and shall apply to all policies
issued, renewed, altered or modified on or after such date.
